\(\sum_{i=1}^{n}f(x_{i})\Delta x\)

where

\(\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}\)

and

\(x_{i} = a + i\Delta x\)

<math>

question: 1 (g)
sols_html:
Notice that \(e^{i/n}\) occurs in the summand. This suggests that \(x_{i} = i/n\) and so we can take \(a = 0\). Writing the sum as

\(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{ie^{i/n}}{n^{2}} = \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{1}{n}\cdot \frac{ie^{i/n}}{n}\)

the last fraction suggests that a possible function is \(f(x) = xe^{x}\) which can be seen by noting that we have

\(f(x_{i}) = \frac{ie^{i/n}}{n}.\)

Also, we have

\(\Delta x = \frac{1}{n} = \frac{b-a}{n}\)

and since \(a=0\) we have that \(b=1\). Combining this gives

\(\lim_{n\to\infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{ie^{i/n}}{n^{2}} = \int_{0}^{1}xe^{x}\,dx\)

completing the question.
